children.value: General setup for Git can be found at ~/.gitconfig.
Push to a remote Git repository
See current status for Git repo
Files that have been added using
can be tracked for staging and committing.
will add all files from this directory recursively.
If you decide that you do not want someGit changes, you can run
. This will unstage a particular file.
If you do not want any of the changes to the file at all, you can run
. This will remove all the changes. If you run
, it will remove all Git changes.

# renaming the file
git mv <old-name> <new-name>
# git will rename the file and ls will confirm
the file, you will find that Git considers this as the old file being deleted while a new one being untracked. Adding the file using
will have Git realise that we are just renaming the file.
If we want to rename the file back, we can just use
will show help for the commit history.
will show you the basic Git history from the most recent to the oldest.
will show one line for each commit, plus a graph history and will decorate the log.
will show the commits from the last three days.
will show the log for a specific file name.
will follow a file back through changes in the commit name.
will show the commit ID, author, diff + more.
Can has the ability to add aliases for other commands.
We could add an alias by running
as an alias for that lengthy command.
will show you the diff between the last commit and current files.
will compare working directory and last commit.
will compare staging with last commit.
To limit comparisons to one file, you can
To compare to a particular command, you can run
to compare from HEAD to the specified commit.
where origin/master is the master branch on remote.
Note that the first commit for each new branch has several labels associated with it. Those labels are just pointers and there won't be any new commits on the new branch until we make one.
Fast-forward commits basically move the commits into the current branch as if there was no branch changes made at all.
This will result with a single merge commit with the branch line being preserved
git merge simple-changes -m "Merging changes from simple changes branch"
When you run merge and run into a conflict, you will be in an "in between" merging state.
To resolve a conflict, you will need to open the conflicted files and see the updates Git has made to show the
vs the branch conflicts separated by
Once the conflicts are resolved, you need to now commit the file. Git will generally create a
file during resolutions that you can ignore or remove post-fix.
Rebase source branch into current branch
Include untracked files in stash (not Git ignored)
Essentially runs git stash apply && git stash drop
Show reflog of what is included in the stash
Creates newchanges branch, switches to branch, applies stash and then drops stash
Create stash associated with a message
Tags are nothing more than labels.
will create a tag - it's known as a lightweight tag.
-a Createds an annotated tag - this will allow you to write release notes etc
This will show tag, tagger, date and tag message with commit ID etc
shows a log of everything that we have done. It's the reference log of the previous 60 days.
to actually go back and forward through history. We can also reset back to the top if required post-reset.

Hard | Removes all changes from staging and working directory
Soft | Points header back to new location
